title: This photo shows a woman who was murdered in 2016 -- she was not nominated for the Pakistan Medical Commission
subtitle: A photo has been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts published in 2019 which claim it shows a dancer nominated by the Pakistani government for the Pakistan Medical Commission, which has regulated the country’s medical profession since October 2019. The claim is false; the photo is a screenshot from a video of dancer Qismat Baig, who was murdered in 2016.
author: factcheck.afp.com
vclaim:
This photo shows a woman who was murdered in 2016 -- she was not nominated for the Pakistan Medical Commission

A photo has been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts published in 2019 which claim it shows a dancer nominated by the Pakistani government for the Pakistan Medical Commission, which has regulated the country’s medical profession since October 2019. The claim is false; the photo is a screenshot from a video of dancer Qismat Baig, who was murdered in 2016.

The photo was published in this Facebook post on October 25, 2019. It has been shared more than 980 times.

The post’s English-language caption states: “lot of congratulation to doctor community ,miss roshuna zafar famous dancer appointetd as member of pakistan medical commity (pmc) by our respected govt of pakistan.hope she will introduce latest dancing guide line and tips in field of medicine .”

Below is a screenshot of the misleading Facebook post:

The medical body referred to in the post was known as the Pakistan Medical and Dental Council up until October 20, 2019, when it’s name changed to the Pakistan Medical Commission (PMC).

This is an official government announcement about the development.

“Roshuna Zafar” post refers to Pakistani development practitioner Roshaneh Zafar, who was appointed to the PMC in October 2019, according to this report published by Pakistan newspaper Dawn on October 25, 2019.

Here is an online document of the minutes from the first meeting of the Pakistan Medical Commission, successor of Pakistan Medical and Dental Council (PMDC), attended by Zafar.

The same image was published here and here on Facebook with a similar claim.

The claim is false. A reverse image search for the photo on Google found the image was a screenshot from this YouTube video of Pakistani dancer Qismat Baig, who was shot dead in 2016.

Below is a screenshot of the YouTube video at the three-minute 25-second mark:

Below is a screenshot comparison of the YouTube video (L) and the misleading Facebook post (R ):

Baig was shot dead in 2016 in the eastern Pakistani city of Lahore, as reported here by Pakistan’s English newspaper Dawn on November 24, 2016.

The report’s headline states: “Stage actor Kismat Baig shot dead by gunmen in Lahore.”

The report states in part: “Stage actor Kismat Baig who was shot eight times by unidentified gunmen in Lahore died on Thursday evening, reported DawnNews.

“Kismat Baig was moved to the emergency ward at Services Hospital after the incident, said Superintendent Police Tahir Rehman.

“The actor was travelling with her driver and personal assistant, both of whom also sustained gunshot wounds.”

Here is Zafar’s official profile on the Pakistan’s National Assembly website.

Below is a screenshot of Zafar’s profile:

Below is a comparison of images of Baig (L) and Zafar (R ):
